Ramai Soal 'Desa Hantu', Ini 'Desa Hantu' di China
06 Nov 2019, 22:50 by Afif Farhan


'Desa hantu' Houtouwan (AFP/Getty Images)

Houtouwan - Baru-baru ini ramai soal 'desa hantu' di Sulawesi Tenggara. Cerita soal 'desa hantu' pun ada di berbagai di dunia, salah satunya di China.Fenomena desa 'hantu' atau desa yang tidak berpenduduk tetapi sengaja didaftarkan demi mendapatkan anggaran dana desa diungkap Menteri Keuangan (Menkeu) Sri Mulyani. Namun rupanya persoalan itu sudah diusut Polda Sulawesi Tenggara (Sultra) dengan bantuan KPK.BACA JUGA: Ternyata Kasus Desa 'Hantu' Sudah Diusut Polri-KPK, Apa Hasilnya?Mari kita membicarakan soal 'desa hantu' tapi dalam arti sesungguhnya. Desa yang diyakini berhantu atau mungkin juga bisa dibilang tidak dihuni manusia sama sekali dan menyisakan bangunan-bangunan.Untuk yang seperti itu, China punya 'desa hantu' yang lagi terkenal. Namanya Desa Houtouwan.BACA JUGA: Cerita Turis-turis yang Memotret Penampakan Hantu


Foto: (AFP/Getty Images)

Desa Houtouwan terletak di Kepulauan Shengshan di sebelah timur Kota Shanghai. Desa Houtouwan sudah ditempati penduduk sejak tahun 1950-an, yang mayoritas penduduknya bermatapencaharian sebagai petani dan nelayan.Namun di tahun 1990-an, perubahan terjadi di desa tersebut. Penduduk desa banyak yang pindah ke China Daratan (Mainland) untuk mencari pekerjaan dan penghidupan yang lebih baik. Akibatnya, lambat laun desa ini mulai kosong, sampai akhirnya sama sekali tak berpenghuni.Di tahun 2015, warga China dihebohkan oleh penampakan Desa Houtouwan. Ada seorang fotografer di sana bernama Qing Jian, yang menelusuri tentang desa tersebut dan melihat panorama yang ngeri tapi juga cantik.


Foto: (AFP/Getty Images)

Hampir semua sudut bangunan di sana tertutup oleh lumut dan tumbuhan merambat lainnya. Rumah-rumah, hingga jalanan pun terlihat menghijau.Meski tertutup lumut dan tumbuhan merambat, kesan terbengkalai dan tidak terawat justru sirna di Desa Houtouwan. Yang tampak justru keindahan dan nuansa hijau sejauh mata memandang.Saat alam mengambil kembali apa yang ditinggalkan oleh manusia, alam justru mengembalikannya ke kondisinya yang paling alami seperti saat sebelum dihuni oleh manusia. Hal yang berkebalikan dengan apa yang dilakukan oleh manusia.Meski tetap saja, suasana desa yang begitu sepi membuat bulu kudu merinding!


Foto: (AFP/Getty Images)

Kini, Desa Houtouwan mulai dilirik lagi untuk dikunjungi turis. Mereka yang datang ke sini biasanya untuk jalan-jalan dan berfoto menikmati nuansa hijau yang berbeda 180 derajat dengan Kota Shanghai.Mulai tahun lalu, pemerintah kota setempat menetapkan tiket masuk bagi wisatawan yang berkunjung ke Houtouwan. Per orangnya, turis wajib membayar 50 Yuan (setara Rp 110 ribuan).Untuk menuju ke sini, turis bisa naik kapal dari pelabuhan di Hangzhou Bay. Hanya butuh waktu kurang dari 2 jam untuk bisa sampai ke sini.Selamat datang di 'desa hantu' China! Simak Video "Mengintip Desa 'Hantu' di Konawe Sultra"[Gambas:Video 20detik](aff/aff)

Crowded About 'Ghost Village', It's 'Ghost Village' in China
Nov 6, 2019, 22:50 by Afif Farhan


Houtouwan's 'ghost village' (AFP / Getty Images)

Houtouwan - Recently there is a lot of buzz about the 'ghost village' in Southeast Sulawesi. Stories about 'ghost villages' also exist in various parts of the world, one of them is in China. The phenomenon of 'ghost villages' or villages that are not populated but deliberately registered in order to get a village fund budget was revealed by the Minister of Finance (Minister of Finance) Sri Mulyani. But apparently the issue has been investigated by the Southeast Sulawesi Regional Police (Southeast Sulawesi) with the help of the KPK. READ ALSO: Apparently the Case of the 'Ghost' Village Has Been Traced by the Police-KPK, What Are the Results? Let's talk about the 'ghost village' but in its true meaning. Villages that are believed to be haunted or may also be practically not inhabited by humans at all and leave buildings. For such, China has a 'ghost village' which is more famous. It's called Houtouwan Village. READ ALSO: The Story of Tourists Taking Photos of Ghost Sightings


Photo: (AFP / Getty Images)

Houtouwan Village is located on the Shengshan Islands in the east of Shanghai City. Houtouwan village has been inhabited by people since the 1950s, the majority of whose inhabitants work as farmers and fishermen. But in the 1990s, changes occurred in the village. Many villagers have moved to Mainland China (Mainland) to find work and better livelihoods. As a result, this village gradually began to empty, until finally completely uninhabited. In 2015, Chinese citizens were shocked by the appearance of Houtouwan Village. There was a photographer there named Qing Jian, who searched about the village and saw a horrifying but beautiful panorama.


Photo: (AFP / Getty Images)

Almost all corners of the building there are covered by moss and other vines. The houses, even the streets look green. Even though they are covered in moss and vines, the impression of being neglected and not maintained actually disappears in Houtouwan Village. What appears is the beauty and shades of green as far as the eye can see. When nature takes back what is left by humans, nature actually returns it to its most natural condition like before it was inhabited by humans. The opposite of what is done by humans. Even still, the village atmosphere is so quiet it makes goose bumps goosebumps!


Photo: (AFP / Getty Images)

Now, Houtouwan Village is starting to be glimpsed again by tourists. Those who come here usually take a walk and take pictures to enjoy the nuances of green that are 180 degrees different from Shanghai City. Starting last year, the local city government set an entrance ticket for tourists visiting Houtouwan. Per person, tourists must pay 50 Yuan (equivalent to Rp 110 thousand). To go here, tourists can take a boat from the port in Hangzhou Bay. It only takes less than 2 hours to get here. Welcome to the 'ghost village' of China!
